awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research : Engineering Hyperstable Enzymes via Computationally Guided Protein Stapling
awd_abstract_narration:
Enzymes are proteins that facilitate reactions. At modest temperatures or in response to pH changes, enzymes will lose their three-dimensional structure which leads to a loss in their activity as catalysts. If enzymes were more stable, then they could be used more widely in industrial applications. This research project will investigate a new method for designing proteins in which chemical links will be made between certain parts of the enzyme, also called "molecular stapling." This method might increase the stability of proteins at elevated temperatures or in the presence of chemicals. The activity of the new enzyme with "staples" should be unchanged from the original enzyme. The results of this project could lead to enzymes that could be designed to manufacture pharmaceuticals or to produce chemicals in a more sustainable manner.  The research project serves as a training ground for undergraduate and graduate students to perform cutting edge research, leading to a skilled STEM workforce. The researchers will host local high school students for a research experience on enzymes and proteins.  They will also participate in outreach to area community colleges.

The idea behind this research project is that enzymes can be stabilized by genetically encoded, redox-stable covalent crosslinks. A novel computational design method for protein stabilization via covalent stapling will be developed via iterative design-build-test cycles, using a carbene transferase as testbed. The scope of this methodology will be extended to different stapling strategies for maximizing both thermodynamic and kinetic stability of the target enzyme, leading to hyperstabilization. Computational methodology development will be guided by detailed investigations of the stapled enzyme variants via functional assays and complementary biophysical techniques. The generality of this approach will be demonstrated through its application for the rapid and efficient thermostabilization of different enzymes of biotechnological importance. It is envisioned that this method will be broadly applicable to enzymes and proteins, providing an effective, and potentially general strategy for protein hyperstabilization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Enzymes are fundamentally important tools in biotechnology and constitute attractive catalysts for sustainable chemical manufacturing and the construction of artificial metabolic pathways in synthetic biology. The marginal stability of proteins, however, poses a fundamental challenge to the exploitation of proteins/enzymes in many of these applications. Current strategies for enzyme stabilization such as directed evolution are time- and labor-intensive and/or require the accumulation of several mutations, often at the expense of enzymatic function and selectivity. In view of these limitations, this collaborative project has developed a new and effective strategy for dramatically enhancing the thermal and chemical stability of an enzyme without impacting its native function. Specifically, this strategy, called Rosetta-Guided Protein Stapling (R-GPS), involves the combined use of genetically encodable strategies for protein crosslinking and Rosetta-based computational tools to guide the design of ‘stapled’ variants of a target enzyme which are stabilized thanks to the introduction of genetically encoded, redox-stable covalent crosslinks within its structure. In a first implementation of this strategy, R-GPS was successfully applied to the stabilization of a carbene transferase as model enzyme, resulting in stapled variants showing a melting temperature (Tm) increased by over 15-20°C compared to the parent enzyme without loss of catalytic function. This strategy was later extended to computationally guided protein stapling using a broader range of non-canonical amino acids, which revealed the beneficial effect of conformationally more rigid ‘stapling modules’ for protein thermostabilization. These efforts produced variants of the carbene transferase with dramatically enhanced stability against thermal denaturation (ΔTm = +27 °C) and temperature-induced cofactor loss (ΔT50 = +30 °C) while retaining high levels of catalytic activity and stereoselectivity. Crystallographic analyses of singly and doubly stapled variants provide key insights into the structural basis for stabilization, which includes both direct interactions of the staples with protein residues and indirect interactions through adjacent residues involved in heme binding. Building upon these findings, additional protein stapling strategies were developed for achieving thermostabilization of a target enzyme or protein via both two- and three-way crosslinking. Ultimately, this project has made available a powerful new tool for enhancing the chemical and thermal stability of a protein/enzyme via computational design. 

At the University of Rochester, this project has provided important opportunities for interdisciplinary training and professional development for a total of seven graduate students and seven undergraduate students, including eight women and four students from underrepresented minorities. Students involved in this project have received hands-on training on state-of-the-art the area of protein engineering, protein chemistry, amber stop codon suppression technologies, and biocatalysis. Professional training for both graduate and undergraduate students participating in this project has been further realized through their participation in report and manuscript writing, through the attendance and presentation of their research findings at local and national scientific meetings, and through frequent and direct interactions with the collaborators’ teams.

Finally, project participants have directly contributed to a yearly outreach initiative, called Early Connections Opportunities, targeted to minority and other disadvantaged students from high schools with limited resources and/or underdeveloped teaching capabilities. Through workshops and other activities organized during the summer, these outreach activities have contributed to introduce and better prepare these minority and socioeconomically disadvantaged students for their future training and education in college.


Last Modified: 12/28/2023
Modified by: Rudi Fasan
